questions.question_text_1: Which of the following best describes the primary advantage of asynchronous updates in web applications?
question_texts: Which of the following best describes the primary advantage of asynchronous updates in web applications?

options.option_text: It ensures that all elements of a web page are loaded at the same time.
It improves performance by allowing parts of a webpage to update withoutrequiring a full reload.
It forces the client to wait until the server responds before interacting with thepage.
It requires a high-speed internet connection to function correctly.

questions.question_text_1: A web server is handling requests and has an 8-core processor, 32 GB of RAM, and a network bandwidth of 500 Mbps. The application running on the server is capable of generating 100 HTML pages every second. Each of these pages includes an image file that is 500 KB in size. What is the maximum number of requests per second that the server can handle?
question_texts: A web server is handling requests and has an 8-core processor, 32 GB of RAM, and a network bandwidth of 500 Mbps. The application running on the server is capable of generating 100 HTML pages every second. Each of these pages includes an image file that is 500 KB in size. What is the maximum number of requests per second that the server can handle?

questions.question_text_1: The lens of an HDD can read data on the rotating disk with the speed of 36,000 bits per second. The disk is designed such that 600 bits pass under the lens for every revolution of the disk. What should be the maximum speed of the disk so that the lens does not miss any data?
question_texts: The lens of an HDD can read data on the rotating disk with the speed of 36,000 bits per second. The disk is designed such that 600 bits pass under the lens for every revolution of the disk. What should be the maximum speed of the disk so that the lens does not miss any data?

props.summary:
### Summary of Core Topics, Concepts, Principles, and Equations #### 1. **Database Systems** - **RDBMS (Relational Database Management System)**: Suitable for structured data and complex queries. Examples include PostgreSQL, MySQL, and SQLite. - **NoSQL Databases**: Suitable for unstructured data. Examples include MongoDB (document-based), Redis (key-value store), and Neo4j (graph database). #### 2. **Web Development Concepts** - **Asynchronous Updates**: Improve performance by allowing parts of a webpage to update without requiring a full reload. - **HTTP Methods**: GET, POST, PUT, DELETE are HTTP request methods used for different operations. - **Client-Server Model**: Differentiates between clients and servers, where clients request services and servers provide them. - **Software Architecture Patterns**: MVC (Model-View-Controller) is a common pattern for organizing code in web applications. #### 3. **Programming Concepts** - **Decorators in Python**: Used to modify the behavior of functions. Example: ```python def update(func): def wrapper(N): out = [] for i in range(N): if i % 2 == 0: out.append(i ** 3) else: out.append(i ** 2) return out return wrapper @update def func(N): if N % 2 == 0: return N ** 2 else: return N ** 3 ``` - **Template Inheritance in Flask**: Allows for the creation of a base template that other templates can extend. Example: ```html {% extends "base_layout.html" %} {% block abc %}

Company Directors

  • Ram
  • Rahim
  • David
{% endblock %} ``` #### 4. **Flask and Web Frameworks** - **Flask Routes**: Define the URLs that the application will respond to. Example: ```python @app.route("/response") def get_response(): if request.args.get("n"): n = request.args.get("n") r = "" for i in range(1, (int(n) + 1)): if is_odd(i): r = r + "odd : " + str(i) + "\n" else: r = r + "even : " + str(i) + "\n" return r else: return "missing parameter 'n' with value" ``` - **Flask-SQLAlchemy**: Used for database operations in Flask. Example: ```python student1 = Student.query.filter_by(First_name="Karthik").first() student1.First_name = "Vikram" db.session.commit() students_list = Student.query.all() ``` #### 5. **Performance and Hardware Constraints** - **Server Capacity**: Understanding the limitations of server hardware (e.g., CPU cores, RAM, network bandwidth) and how they affect the number of requests a server can handle. - **Disk Speed**: Calculating the maximum speed of a disk to ensure data is read correctly. Example equation: \[ \text{Speed (RPM)} = \frac{\text{Read Speed (bits per second)}}{\text{Bits per Revolution}} \] #### 6. **Error Handling and Status Codes** - **HTTP Status Codes**: Understanding different status codes like 200 (OK), 404 (Not Found), etc. - **Error Handling in Flask**: Using decorators like `@app.errorhandler(404)` to handle errors gracefully. ### Mermaid Knowledge Graph ```mermaid graph TD; A[Database Systems] --> B[RDBMS] A --> C[NoSQL] B --> D[PostgreSQL] B --> E[MySQL] B --> F[SQLite] C --> G[MongoDB] C --> H[Redis] C --> I[Neo4j] J[Web Development] --> K[Asynchronous Updates] J --> L[HTTP Methods] J --> M[Client-Server Model] J --> N[Software Architecture Patterns] O[Programming Concepts] --> P[Decorators in Python] O --> Q[Template Inheritance in Flask] R[Flask and Web Frameworks] --> S[Flask Routes] R --> T[Flask-SQLAlchemy] U[Performance and Hardware Constraints] --> V[Server Capacity] U --> W[Disk Speed] X[Error Handling and Status Codes] --> Y[HTTP Status Codes] X --> Z[Error Handling in Flask] ``` ```mermaid graph TD; A[Database Systems] --> B[RDBMS] A --> C[NoSQL] B --> D[PostgreSQL] B --> E[MySQL] B --> F[SQLite] C --> G[MongoDB] C --> H[Redis] C --> I[Neo4j] J[Web Development] --> K[Asynchronous Updates] J --> L[HTTP Methods] J --> M[Client-Server Model] J --> N[Software Architecture Patterns] O[Programming Concepts] --> P[Decorators in Python] O --> Q[Template Inheritance in Flask] R[Flask and Web Frameworks] --> S[Flask Routes] R --> T[Flask-SQLAlchemy] U[Performance and Hardware Constraints] --> V[Server Capacity] U --> W[Disk Speed] X[Error Handling and Status Codes] --> Y[HTTP Status Codes] X --> Z[Error Handling in Flask] ``` This summary and the knowledge graph should help you understand the core topics and their relationships, making it easier to prepare for the exam.
